description: The Microsoft Exchange 2016 Exam 70-345 show will help the experienced Exchange Admin who is already familiar with Microsoft Exchange but need to plan, deploy, manage and troubleshoot different components of Microsoft Exchange 2016.  You’ll see powershell and Exchange Admin Center commands that will help to maintain and manage Mailbox Databases, Client Access Services, Transport services, Coexistence and Migration scenarios.  Exchange Expert Brian Svidergol takes each topic in detail and focuses in on the skills measured to give clear understanding of each domain objective called out Microsoft for Exam 70-345
descriptionMD: The Microsoft Exchange 2016 Exam 70-345 show will help the experienced Exchange Admin who is already familiar with Microsoft Exchange but need to plan, deploy, manage and troubleshoot different components of Microsoft Exchange 2016.  You’ll see powershell and Exchange Admin Center commands that will help to maintain and manage Mailbox Databases, Client Access Services, Transport services, Coexistence and Migration scenarios.  Exchange Expert Brian Svidergol takes each topic in detail and focuses in on the skills measured to give clear understanding of each domain objective called out Microsoft for Exam 70-345
name: Microsoft Exchange Server 2016 - 70-345
subtitle: Designing and Deploying Microsoft Exchange Server 2016

episodes.description: The Microsoft Exchange 2016 Exam 70-345 show will help the experienced Exchange Admin who is already familiar with Microsoft Exchange but need to plan, deploy, manage and troubleshoot different components of Microsoft Exchange 2016. You’ll see powershell and Exchange Admin Center commands that will help to maintain and manage Mailbox Databases, Client Access Services, Transport services, Coexistence and Migration scenarios. Exchange Expert Brian Svidergol takes each topic in detail and focuses in on the skills measured to give clear understanding of each domain objective called out Microsoft for Exam 70-345
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:04.893
[SOUND] Hello,
we're about to begin a show on

2
00:00:04.893 --> 00:00:10.954
Microsoft Exchange 2016 for Exam 70-345.

3
00:00:10.954 --> 00:00:13.870
You want to make sure that you're
actually ready to take the exam, so

4
00:00:13.870 --> 00:00:16.520
we're actually have an entire
show based on that.

5
00:00:16.520 --> 00:00:19.130
Before we get started let's talk
a little bit about getting ready for

6
00:00:19.130 --> 00:00:20.590
that exam as well.

7
00:00:20.590 --> 00:00:24.690
Once you're fully prepared, make sure that
you go to your Pearson Vue testing center,

8
00:00:24.690 --> 00:00:27.550
and get registered,
you can do that online as well.

9
00:00:27.550 --> 00:00:29.230
But wherever you are in the world,

10
00:00:29.230 --> 00:00:31.520
make sure you also know that
you're gonna have to pay a fee for

11
00:00:31.520 --> 00:00:36.290
the exam as well, currently, right now
in the United States, it's about $165.

12
00:00:36.290 --> 00:00:38.480
Make sure you check your local rates, and

13
00:00:38.480 --> 00:00:41.030
you actually find out what
the price is going to be.

14
00:00:41.030 --> 00:00:43.990
Once you're registered, you'll go
there on the day of the exam, sit for

15
00:00:43.990 --> 00:00:47.790
the exam and then, of course hopefully,
pass the exam as well.

16
00:00:47.790 --> 00:00:52.070
But to ensure that you are ready and
prepared for that, in our show we're gonna

17
00:00:52.070 --> 00:00:55.760
have Mr. Brian as being our subject
matter expert to help us out.

18
00:00:55.760 --> 00:00:58.570
So Brian, what are we gonna
be covering during our show?

19
00:00:59.720 --> 00:01:05.500
>> Thanks Ronnie, so we've actually got,
this exam has six primary topics, and

20
00:01:05.500 --> 00:01:10.550
each of the six topics represents
about 15 or 20% of the exam.

21
00:01:10.550 --> 00:01:14.830
So, the bad news is,
you can't focus on one topic because

22
00:01:14.830 --> 00:01:17.600
they're all evenly spread throughout,
you're gonna need to know a little bit

23
00:01:17.600 --> 00:01:19.532
about all these things to get ready for
the exam.

24
00:01:19.532 --> 00:01:23.100
While we walk you through some of
the topics, we're gonna start at the top,

25
00:01:23.100 --> 00:01:29.310
the first one is plan deploy, manage,
and troubleshoot mailbox databases.

26
00:01:29.310 --> 00:01:32.060
So this is all about the database side,

27
00:01:32.060 --> 00:01:35.660
it starts off with a lot
of sizing components.

28
00:01:35.660 --> 00:01:38.590
How many databases do you need,
how much storage do you need?

29
00:01:38.590 --> 00:01:44.050
So one of things you want to focus on,
is how to size an environment if you're

30
00:01:44.050 --> 00:01:47.486
given a certain set of circumstances, like
maybe you have a couple of thousand users,

31
00:01:47.486 --> 00:01:51.290
they each have a two gig mailbox,
they send 100 messages a day.

32
00:01:51.290 --> 00:01:54.370
The tool that you want to take a look at,
make sure you're familiar with,

33
00:01:54.370 --> 00:01:57.130
is Exchange Server sizing calculator.

34
00:01:57.130 --> 00:02:00.850
That's that spreadsheet that will help
you calculate out the environment,

35
00:02:00.850 --> 00:02:01.510
the storage,

36
00:02:01.510 --> 00:02:05.750
even the bandwidth if you decide to
go with database availability groups.

37
00:02:05.750 --> 00:02:10.450
So on the database side, there's a ton
of topics, you're also gonna dive into

38
00:02:10.450 --> 00:02:14.970
creating databases, managing databases,
mounting and dismounting,

39
00:02:14.970 --> 00:02:19.900
maybe get into a little bit of that
stuff too, so that's topic number one.

40
00:02:19.900 --> 00:02:26.090
For topic number two plan, deploy, manage,
and troubleshoot Client Access services.

41
00:02:26.090 --> 00:02:32.510
So, what we're talking about here is
the client population like your end users,

42
00:02:32.510 --> 00:02:35.970
and how they get to all the services
that exchange has to offer.

43
00:02:35.970 --> 00:02:39.750
So, we're talking about everything
from Outlook connectivity,

44
00:02:39.750 --> 00:02:43.960
to Outlook on the web, to mobile devices,

45
00:02:43.960 --> 00:02:47.910
anyway that anybody can get in and
consume the Exchange Services.

46
00:02:47.910 --> 00:02:50.460
There's a whole bunch of
topics to cover down here,

47
00:02:50.460 --> 00:02:53.760
I wanna point out a couple of them.

48
00:02:53.760 --> 00:02:59.200
We have a little bit on authentication,
knowing about form-based authentication,

49
00:02:59.200 --> 00:03:05.130
kerberos based authentication, how to set
that stuff, we get into client namespaces,

50
00:03:05.130 --> 00:03:07.990
all the names that people use,
and have to remember.

51
00:03:07.990 --> 00:03:13.460
You think about mail.yourdomain.com, can
you use that across the whole environment,

52
00:03:13.460 --> 00:03:18.360
where do you set that stuff up, and
does it need to be different internally,

53
00:03:18.360 --> 00:03:19.450
externally?

54
00:03:19.450 --> 00:03:20.013
All right,

55
00:03:20.013 --> 00:03:24.130
a lot of planning considerations
around the Client Access pieces.

56
00:03:24.130 --> 00:03:28.900
And then also in there, we talk about
some of the networking pieces, too,

57
00:03:28.900 --> 00:03:31.510
like load balancing, and

58
00:03:33.010 --> 00:03:37.170
even some site resiliency when it comes
to getting the clients connected.

59
00:03:37.170 --> 00:03:40.778
So that's high level topic number two.

60
00:03:40.778 --> 00:03:45.125
The third one is the exchange,
infrastructure, recipients and

61
00:03:45.125 --> 00:03:49.330
security, planning,
deploying, and managing.

62
00:03:49.330 --> 00:03:52.825
What you'll find in there is a lot
of stuff on Active Directory,

63
00:03:52.825 --> 00:03:55.960
preparing Active Directory
to have exchange.

64
00:03:55.960 --> 00:03:59.740
We're talking about schema updates,
domain preparation, and

65
00:04:01.160 --> 00:04:07.115
the other pieces are around security,
mail unable to object permissions.

66
00:04:07.115 --> 00:04:09.800
These is a very tough area,

67
00:04:09.800 --> 00:04:13.650
all the permission stuff, we have
a lot of role based access control, so

68
00:04:13.650 --> 00:04:17.580
a couple of things I wanna point out here,
how do we give our administrators

69
00:04:17.580 --> 00:04:21.480
access to the environment,
without giving them more than they need?

70
00:04:21.480 --> 00:04:24.110
So it's all about the principle
of least privilege right?

71
00:04:24.110 --> 00:04:26.270
Your gonna need to know
the built in roles,

72
00:04:26.270 --> 00:04:28.850
your gonna need to know
how to customize them.

73
00:04:28.850 --> 00:04:34.060
On the permission side, we're gonna dive
into anything from mailbox permissions,

74
00:04:34.060 --> 00:04:36.220
to public folder permission.

75
00:04:36.220 --> 00:04:39.590
How do you give other people
access to somebody's mailbox?

76
00:04:39.590 --> 00:04:41.410
Think about shared mailboxes, and

77
00:04:41.410 --> 00:04:44.410
what if you just wanted to
give them access to a folder?

78
00:04:44.410 --> 00:04:46.689
You've got a lot of granularity there, and

79
00:04:46.689 --> 00:04:49.902
these are the details you're
gonna need to know for the exam.

80
00:04:49.902 --> 00:04:52.110
All right,
let's talk about the next topic.

81
00:04:54.450 --> 00:04:59.270
Plan, deploy, manage compliance,
archiving, eDiscovery, and auditing.

82
00:04:59.270 --> 00:05:00.950
So this is an interesting one,

83
00:05:00.950 --> 00:05:06.600
very closely related to security,
there is a turnout detail here.

84
00:05:06.600 --> 00:05:10.150
When we talk about compliance and
archiving,

85
00:05:10.150 --> 00:05:14.907
what we are talking about is, do we need
to maintain data at the organisation, and

86
00:05:14.907 --> 00:05:18.720
if so how long, and
if we do, how do we do that?

87
00:05:18.720 --> 00:05:22.800
We can go with archiving as one example,
when we thing of archiving,

88
00:05:22.800 --> 00:05:26.920
that's taking your mail data,
and keeping it for the long term.

89
00:05:26.920 --> 00:05:30.350
There's a lot of choices and planning
considerations, for example, do you wanna

90
00:05:30.350 --> 00:05:34.130
keep that archiving data on premises,
or do you wanna move it up to the Cloud,

91
00:05:34.130 --> 00:05:36.280
what are the different things
you need to think about there?

92
00:05:36.280 --> 00:05:42.630
When we talk about eDiscovery, we're
talking about the ability for the security

93
00:05:42.630 --> 00:05:46.890
team to take a look at all of the mail
data throughout the whole environment,

94
00:05:46.890 --> 00:05:50.640
looking for something maybe to do with
a legal case or something similar.

95
00:05:50.640 --> 00:05:54.435
For the exam, you're gonna need to know
how to set up eDiscovery, how to run

96
00:05:54.435 --> 00:05:58.730
eDiscovery, and what permissions at
you're gonna need in order to do that.

97
00:05:58.730 --> 00:06:03.170
And then finally, auditing for
this particular topic.

98
00:06:03.170 --> 00:06:07.270
Auditing is capturing all of
the actions that were performed

99
00:06:07.270 --> 00:06:10.580
typically by an administrator
while they're doing their job.

100
00:06:10.580 --> 00:06:13.833
Which commandlets did they run,
which parameters, who ran it,

101
00:06:13.833 --> 00:06:15.940
what did they run, what did they change?

102
00:06:15.940 --> 00:06:17.920
You're gonna need that stuff
when you wanna go back and

103
00:06:17.920 --> 00:06:23.185
figure out what caused maybe an outage or
some kind of bad configuration change.

104
00:06:23.185 --> 00:06:25.435
In addition to
the administrative side though,

105
00:06:25.435 --> 00:06:29.095
you can also do auditing on
the mailboxes themselves.

106
00:06:29.095 --> 00:06:31.435
So if you're ever in a trouble shooting
situation and you wanna figure out,

107
00:06:31.435 --> 00:06:35.745
what's going on with the user's mailbox,
you can turn on auditing on the mailbox

108
00:06:35.745 --> 00:06:39.895
for specific actions, whether they're
creates, or deletes, or removes, and

109
00:06:39.895 --> 00:06:42.685
in troubleshooting scenarios,
you can dig that data up.

110
00:06:42.685 --> 00:06:45.810
So you're definitely gonna
need to know about that.

111
00:06:45.810 --> 00:06:50.180
And then our final topic is implement and
manage coexistence,

112
00:06:50.180 --> 00:06:54.460
hybrid scenarios,
migration, and federation.

113
00:06:54.460 --> 00:06:59.000
This is a whole flurry of topics,
and their big ones too.

114
00:06:59.000 --> 00:07:04.000
This is where we'll get into
a little bit of Office 365,

115
00:07:04.000 --> 00:07:06.810
when you think about taking your
on premises environment, and

116
00:07:06.810 --> 00:07:11.020
configuring it to be a hybrid
environment with Office 365.

117
00:07:11.020 --> 00:07:15.110
Maybe you're gonna have some mailboxes
on-premises, maybe you're gonna have some

118
00:07:15.110 --> 00:07:18.471
in the Cloud, maybe you're gonna
move everything into the Cloud, but

119
00:07:18.471 --> 00:07:20.712
you're gonna need that
co-existence time for

120
00:07:20.712 --> 00:07:22.866
a little while where you
have to manage both.

121
00:07:22.866 --> 00:07:26.560
You're gonna need to know the details
around that set-up process,

122
00:07:26.560 --> 00:07:29.553
what are the requirement,
how do users authenticate,

123
00:07:29.553 --> 00:07:32.620
do we need to do any sinking
up to Azure Active Directory?

124
00:07:34.400 --> 00:07:39.630
Beyond that we get into migration and
coexistence from earlier version,

125
00:07:39.630 --> 00:07:45.609
so think about Exchange 2010 or 2013, you
wanna bring 2016 into your environment,

126
00:07:46.620 --> 00:07:51.350
how do you do that, what are you gonna
need to know, what do you do once it's in?

127
00:07:51.350 --> 00:07:54.140
And then how do you get
rid of the old stuff, so

128
00:07:54.140 --> 00:07:55.570
there's a bunch of topics around that.

129
00:07:55.570 --> 00:07:59.580
Everything from moving mailboxes
whether individually or

130
00:07:59.580 --> 00:08:02.340
in batches, moving the public folders.

131
00:08:02.340 --> 00:08:06.000
And then the last little piece you
need to move before you can start

132
00:08:06.000 --> 00:08:09.080
the decommissioning process, and
there's a lot of details even

133
00:08:09.080 --> 00:08:13.510
around the decommissioning process, and
I think that are covered here on the exam.

134
00:08:13.510 --> 00:08:19.130
So, that's quite a bit of stuff here,
I do have one more that I left off,

135
00:08:19.130 --> 00:08:24.740
and that's the plan, deploy, manage and
troubleshoot transport services.

136
00:08:24.740 --> 00:08:28.540
So, transport services
are the backend services that

137
00:08:28.540 --> 00:08:33.850
handle the flow of email data, when you
send an email from one person to another,

138
00:08:33.850 --> 00:08:38.330
whether it's inside the company,
or maybe out to the internet.

139
00:08:38.330 --> 00:08:42.710
There's a whole transport pipeline
architecture, some of which is new to

140
00:08:42.710 --> 00:08:46.250
Exchange 2016, that you're gonna
need to know the details about.

141
00:08:46.250 --> 00:08:49.660
You wanna really know, how does
an email get from one place to another,

142
00:08:49.660 --> 00:08:53.730
how does it choose which route to go down,
what are the infrastructure

143
00:08:53.730 --> 00:08:58.750
considerations to change that routing,
maybe enhance a little bit?

144
00:08:58.750 --> 00:09:00.820
We're gonna dive into
those details in the show,

145
00:09:00.820 --> 00:09:03.390
so that you're comfortable as you
get those topics on your exam.

146
00:09:04.870 --> 00:09:09.760
So, that is a breakdown of high level of
everything we want to cover on this show.

147
00:09:09.760 --> 00:09:14.900
We're gonna dive into when we talk
across the topic a lot of PowerShell.

148
00:09:14.900 --> 00:09:19.470
So, most everything today, from an
administrative prospective, you can do it

149
00:09:19.470 --> 00:09:24.260
from the GUI components, like Exchange
admin center or from PowerShell.

150
00:09:24.260 --> 00:09:27.960
For exam preparation,
I like to focus on the PowerShell pieces,

151
00:09:27.960 --> 00:09:30.350
because those are the most testable.

152
00:09:30.350 --> 00:09:33.680
So, you'll see, we're gonna cover
a lot of the command line, but

153
00:09:33.680 --> 00:09:36.500
when it's appropriate,
we're also gonna go into the Gooey,

154
00:09:36.500 --> 00:09:40.510
because sometimes it shows you
a good end user experience and

155
00:09:40.510 --> 00:09:43.560
what the impacts and
effects of some of these changes are.

156
00:09:43.560 --> 00:09:47.580
So, be prepared for a lot of PowerShell,
and let's get ready.

157
00:09:48.610 --> 00:09:53.790
If you think that you're gonna be
taking the exam 70-345, then we have

158
00:09:53.790 --> 00:09:58.596
all this information coming
up in the show, stay tuned.

159
00:09:58.596 --> 00:10:01.459
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie discuss and examine the concepts of planning for Mailbox Database in Exchange 2016.  They discuss the use of the planning calculator, storage capacity and storage architecture considerations.  Also covered are planning uses such as auto reseed and basic virtualization requirements too.
episodes.title: Plan Deploy and Manage Mailbox DBs

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie take a look at creating and managing task for validating and creating the mailbox databases. Brian shows how to setup the JetStress, create and configure the mailbox database using powershell and manage the created mailbox database using the GUI.  The last topic he emphasizes is the configuring the transaction log and how to move them.
episodes.title: Plan Deploy and Manage Mailbox DBs Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie begin with planning, deploying and managing the high-availability solutions for mailbox databases.  They identify failure domains, discuss solutions that meet SLA requirements, plan out software updates and maintenance. Brian also describes a change management.  Brian also demonstrates how to setup a DAG and add elements to make it work!
episodes.title: HA Solutions for Mailbox DBs

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie discuss the need for setting up a File Share Witness (FSW).  The discuss the need and take a look at configuring it in Azure as well ask discuss hosting a DAG in the cloud.
episodes.title: HA Solutions for Mailbox DBs Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie dive into the concepts of site-resilient DAGs.  Brian describes the considerations of placing the FSW for a given scenario.  They discuss the idea of cross-site DAGs.  He shows how to configure for the DAC—Dataceter Activation Coordination and they mention the used of an alternate fileshare witness.
episodes.title: Site-Resilient Database Availability Group

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Brian begin guiding viewers through the aspects troubleshooting mailbox DBs.  They run commands to help to test the replication health and look at performance issues. Also They demonstration how to troubleshoot the DB copy activation and failures.  Brian describes issues surrounding quorum issues that may arise and help us to understand the concept of data center activation.
episodes.title: Monitor and Troubleshoot Mailbox DBs

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Brian examine the of the backup and recovery solutions for the mailbox databases.  The mention RTO and RPO requirements, lagged mailboxes, failures, public folders and the dial tone restore!
episodes.title: Backup and Recover Mailbox DBs

topics.title: Plan, deploy, manage, and troubleshoot mailbox databases

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Brian discuss Client Access Services requirements and considerations.  They discuss name space considerations for CAS.  Brian then describes the differences between proxying and redirection.  He shows how to deploy the certificates to the exchange components and some additional service setups.
episodes.title: Client Access Services

episodes.description: {Description}In this episode, Brian and Ronnie introduce us to the authentication components, as well as the Offline Address Book, the Hierarchical Address List and Address Book Policies.  The emphasize how to configure and when to use those services.  Each of these services, according to Brian help end user experience.
episodes.title: Client Access Services Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Brian discuss the topics of mobility and loadbalancing.  Brian introduces a guest expert, Elias Mereb to help configure OWA for devices, to demonstrate how to configure Allow Block Quarantine and configuring for Office Apps.  Brian and Ronnie also discuss briefly the issues configuring namespace load balancing and affinity.  As well as cover the topics of layer 4 and layer 7 load balancing methods.
episodes.title: Mobility and Load Balancing

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Brian take a look into troubleshooting some of the common items in Exchange such as Outlook Anywhere, Outlook MAPI over HTTP, Exchange Web Services and Outlook on the Web.  They demonstrate the commands and utilities that will help you get the bottom of your connectivity issues with Exchange 2016
episodes.title: Troubleshoot Client Connectivity

episodes.description: In the episode, Ronnie and Brian continue with troubleshooting pop and map, authentication, autodiscover, ActiveSync and redirection and proxy.  Brian discusses and demonstrates the tools available in each case of when and where to use them for the best results in troubleshooting Exchange 2016 connectivity issues.
episodes.title: Troubleshoot Client Connectivity Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie take a look at some familiar topics from site-resiliency perspective.  They review namespaces and describe the different models involved.  They discuss the basics of site failover and switchover by distinguishing them and reminding us of the importance of the witness server, they review the reduced requirements of certificate and expected client behaviors during failover and switchover
episodes.title: Site Resilient Client Access Services

topics.title: Plan, deploy, manage, and troubleshoot client access services

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie begin with planning transport services.  The discuss the implications of making sure that the Transport Service meets the SLA requirements listed.  Along with this, they plan for both inter-site mail flow and inter-org mail flow and redundant intra-site scenarios.  Another consideration is also planning the use of SafetyNet and Shadow Redundancy.  Lastly they take look at planning for multiple services that must be considered for the transport services to be ready to go.
episodes.title: Plan Deploy and Manage Transport

episodes.description: In this episode Brian and Ronnie dive into troubleshooting the exchange 2016 transport services.  They take a look at the exchange logs and emphasize using powershell to help format tranport logs for readabiiity.  Brian also helps to identify issues for using a shared namespace and SMTP mail flow. They take a look at mail flow issues and TLS issues and take a look at new issues dealing with the Transport Architecture.
episodes.title: Troubleshoot and Monitor Transport Services

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie examine common topics already covered previously with a focus on the transport services.  They discuss and show the use of the preference values for MX records for failover.  Brian describes the resubmission and rerouting queues that need managing and show their default settings.  Along with these topics, Brian and Ronnie take a look at send/receive connectors for site resiliency and describe consideration for transport failover and switchover.
episodes.title: Message Hygiene

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie examine common topics already covered previously with a focus on the transport services.  They discuss and show the use of the preference values for MX records for failover.  Brian describes the resubmission and rerouting queues that need managing and show their default settings.  Along with these topics, Brian and Ronnie take a look at send/receive connectors for site resiliency and describe consideration for transport failover and switchover.
episodes.title: Site Resilient Transport Services

topics.title: Plan, deploy, manage, and troubleshoot transport services

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie take a look at the preparing AD DS for exchange installation.  They describe some of the planning considerations for the number of DCs and GCS.  They also discuss DNS changes that may be required for Exchange.  Brian then demonstrates Extending the Active Directory Schema through powershell as well as preparing all the domains in the forest.  The guys briefly describe site topology considerations.  Brian takes the times to configure a throttling policy to minimize the impact of big volume users of Exchange.
episodes.title: Active Directory DS for Exchange

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie begin with creating and configuring mail-enable_objects.  They demonstrate how to create an existingAD user’s  mailbox as well as how to create the AD user and Mailbox with a single command. They also create resource and room mailboxes for scheduling and configure users and contacts.  Brian configures a distribution list and emphasizes its usage along with linked mailboxes so users can share the same source address and he sets up public folders for the exchange environment.
episodes.title: Mail Enabled Objects

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie take a look at mail-enabled object permission.  This is view that affects and is noticed by the end-users of exchange.  They describe the difference between “Send As” and “Send-On_Behalf”.  They also describe the effects of using mailbox folder permissions and mailbox permissions.  Brian shows setting up the room mailbox delegates to work and configuring auto-mapping and lastly, he configures the public folder permissions.
episodes.title: Mail Enabled Object Permissions

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie take a dive into the RBAC used by Exchange 2016.  They discuss the use of built in groups and cmdlets.  They demonstrate how to configure custom-scoped groups and used unscoped roles too.  Brian give a brief overview for an delegated setup for exchange and what is involved.  He also demonstrates some of the most common poweshell commands used in troubleshooting and describes the use of user assignment policies
episodes.title: Role Based Access Control (RBAC)

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie take a look at using Bitlocker and S/MIME as part of planning an exchange security strategy.  Brian demonstrates enabling the Bitlocker Encryption and shows how we can verify its configuration.  They discuss some of the performance issues and options that are available during its setup.  Brian also discusses S/MIME to secure messages between users.  Brian demonstrate how it’s enabled and what requirements there are for using it.
episodes.title: Plan a Security Strategy

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie introduce the topic of Information Rights Management and the implementation using AD Rights Management and Azure RMS.  Brian also describes the difference between these two implementation. Next Brian takes us through using RMS Templates as the basis for setting up Rights Management in the Exchange Admin Center. He demonstrates Transport Protection Rules and describes how this used to protect our email after it’s sent outbound. The guys contrast that withOutlook Protection rules which protects messages before the arrive in the mailbox.  Brian also reviews  journal report decryption, eDiscovery, pre-licensing.  They end episode reviewing the troubleshooting tools and where to begin.
episodes.title: IRM with AD Rights Mgmt and Azure RMS

topics.title: Plan, deploy, and manage an Exchange infrastructure, recipients, and security

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie take a look at implementing the DLP according to a business need.  They describe the concept and the use of templates as a starting point.  They show the default templates and how to implement them.  Also described by the guys is the ability to customize rules and set policies for the DLP.  Brian then also demonstrates how to create a blank template that has to be manually configured too.  Lastly, they complete the topic by demonstrating Exchange DLP thumbprinting for the company data that is not part of the normal of the PII information covered.
episodes.title: Data Loss Prevention DLP

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie discuss and demonstrate Exchange 2016 archiving and MRM.  They show how to configure retention polices and create custom tag, then associate them together to be applied to users.  Brian demonstrates how the policies are applied by the Managed Folder Assistant and how to remove and delete tags.  The guys discuss the idea of using online archiving such as Office 365, mentioning the perquisites and considerations.  Lastly they create archive policies and configure in-place archiving.
episodes.title: Archiving and MRM

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie cover using eDiscovery.  They emphasize the need of using the RBAC role for eDiscovery.  They configure a litigation hold on a mailbox to show how it can be used, these hold can take up to 60 minutes to be enabled or disabled.  Brian performs a query-based InPlace hold on a single mailbox and then multiple-mailbox discovery.  Last topic the guys cover is working with Microsoft Sharepoint’s Discovery to do a federated search.
episodes.title: Plan Configure and Perform eDiscovery

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie breakdown compliance tasks for Exchange 2016.  They configure MailTips and Message Classifications to help users with compliance.  Brian sets up the transport rules to limit the sending of messages and he takes a look at configuring journaling for compliance. Lastly, Brian addresses and demonstrates how to enable auditing for the mailbox owner and the exchange administrator.
episodes.title: Plan Configure and Manage Compliance

topics.title: Plan, deploy, and manage compliance, archiving, eDiscovery, and auditing

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie help us to get started with an hybrid coexistence with Exchange Online.  They briefly mention the prerequisites for making it work and then run through the Hybrid Configuration Wizard to help show the setup.  The guys also emphasize the use of OAuth for authentication in hybrid deployments and the technologies dependent on it.  Brian describes the certificate and firewall issues that may also cause issues with the hybrid deployment.  They end the episode by troubleshooting transport and client access issues with Exchange online and Directory Synchronization.
episodes.title: Coexistence with Office 365

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie cover the Exchange Federation concepts.  They describe the connecting to the Azure AD Authentication System.  They also take a look at managing the sharing policies and organizational relationship.  Brian also reminds us that we must be concerned with certificates and firewall ports.  They close out the show with troubleshooting the Federation Trusts, Organizational Relationship and Cross-Forest Availability.
episodes.title: Exchange Federation

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie discuss some of the considerations when working in a environment with Exchange 2016 and earlier versions of Exchange.  They take a look at planning for names spaces for coexistence, show the planning of proxy redirection, mail flow, mailbox migrations, transport services and client access.
episodes.title: Coexistence with Earlier Exchange Versions

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie take a look at migrating from earlier versions of Exchange to Exchange 2016.  They describe and distinguished different migration paths depending on the scenario.  Also, the guys take a look at migrating mailboxes, migrating to modern public folders.  Brian also helps us to consider planning for features found in earlier versions of Exchange that are de-emphasized or discontinued in Exchange 2016.  With his experience, Brian brings up considerations for transitioning and decommissioning servers before final steps of getting rid of earlier Exchange servers and takes a look at troubleshooting the Mailbox Replication Services.
episodes.title: Migrate from Earlier Exchange Versions

topics.title: Implement and manage coexistence, hybrid scenarios, migration, and federation
